living_organisms.definition: Living organisms are things that can grow, move, reproduce, and respond to their surroundings.
examples: A child grows taller each year.
A plant grows new leaves when watered.
A puppy becomes a dog over time.

non_living_things.definition: Non-living things do not grow, reproduce, or respond like living things.
examples: A pencil stays the same size forever.
A stone does not need food or water.
A chair cannot move by itself.

growth.definition: Growth is the increase in size, height, or amount of a living thing.
examples: A green gram seed becomes a tall plant.
Your shoes become too small as you grow.
A kitten grows into a cat.

nutrition.definition: Nutrition is how living organisms get and use food for survival.
examples: Eating rice and curry gives you energy.
A cow eats grass to stay healthy.
Plants make food from sunlight.

photosynthesis.definition: Photosynthesis is how green plants make their own food using sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide.
examples: A mango tree makes food in its green leaves.
Plants need sunlight to stay green and healthy.
Leaves turn yellow when they cannot make food.

respiration.definition: Respiration is the process of taking in oxygen and releasing carbon dioxide to produce energy.
examples: Your chest moves up and down when you breathe.
You breathe faster after running in the playground.
A dog pants with its tongue out after playing.

movement.definition: Movement is the ability of living things to change position or show motion.
examples: A mimosa plant closes its leaves when you touch it.
A butterfly flies from flower to flower.
A fish swims in the tank.

reproduction.definition: Reproduction is when living organisms produce new members of their own kind.
examples: A hen lays eggs that hatch into chicks.
A coconut tree grows from a coconut seed.
A cat gives birth to kittens.

micro_organisms.definition: Micro-organisms are tiny living things that cannot be seen with the naked eye.
examples: Germs in dirty water can make you sick.
Yeast makes bread dough rise and become fluffy.
Bacteria in yogurt help digestion.

autotrophic.definition: Autotrophic organisms can make their own food.
examples: A coconut tree makes its own food in the leaves.
Green plants do not need to eat other living things.
A mango tree gets food from sunlight, not from soil.

heterotrophic.definition: Heterotrophic organisms cannot make their own food and must eat other organisms.
examples: A cow eats grass to get energy.
You eat rice and vegetables for food.
A lion hunts deer for its meals.

matter.definition: Matter is anything that has mass and occupies space.
examples: A book has weight and takes up space on the desk.
Water fills the bottle and has mass.
Air inside a balloon has weight.

energy.definition: Energy is the ability to do work and does not have mass or occupy space.
examples: Sunlight helps you see but has no weight.
The sound of a bell travels but has no mass.
Heat from fire warms you but takes no space.

solid.definition: A solid has a definite shape and a definite volume.
examples: A brick keeps its rectangular shape.
A cricket bat does not change shape when you hold it.
A stone stays the same size and shape.

liquid.definition: A liquid has a definite volume but takes the shape of its container.
examples: Water poured into a cup takes the cup's shape.
Milk in a bottle becomes bottle-shaped.
Coconut oil spreads flat in a plate.

gas.definition: A gas has no definite shape or volume and fills its entire container.
examples: Air fills the whole room evenly.
Smoke from incense spreads everywhere.
The smell of food cooking reaches every corner.

hardness.definition: Hardness is the property of a material to resist scratching or cutting.
examples: A diamond can scratch glass easily.
An iron nail is harder than wood.
You cannot scratch a stone with your fingernail.

malleability.definition: Malleability is the ability of a metal to be hammered into thin sheets.
examples: Gold is beaten into thin sheets for jewelry.
Aluminum foil is made by rolling aluminum flat.
Copper sheets are made by hammering copper.

ductility.definition: Ductility is the ability of a metal to be drawn into thin wires.
examples: Copper is pulled into thin wires for electrical cables.
Gold can be made into very thin threads.
Aluminum wires are drawn from aluminum metal.

elasticity.definition: Elasticity is the property of a material to return to its original shape after stretching.
examples: A rubber band stretches and comes back to normal.
A balloon shrinks back after you release the air.
An elastic in your hair can be stretched and relaxed.

brittleness.definition: Brittleness is the tendency of a material to break easily under force.
examples: A glass bottle shatters when dropped on the floor.
Chalk breaks into pieces when pressed hard.
A clay pot cracks easily if hit.

precipitation.definition: Precipitation is water falling from the sky in forms like rain, snow, or hail.
examples: Rain falls during the monsoon season.
Morning dew appears on grass.
Water drops fall from clouds onto the ground.

surface_water.definition: Surface water is water that remains on top of the ground in rivers, lakes, and ponds.
examples: A river flows above the ground.
The tank near your school stores water on the surface.
A puddle forms on the road after rain.

ground_water.definition: Ground water is water that flows and is stored beneath the earth's surface.
examples: Well water comes from underground.
A tube well pumps water from below the ground.
Water seeps into the soil and collects underground.

fresh_water.definition: Fresh water has very little dissolved salt and is suitable for drinking.
examples: River water is fresh and drinkable.
Well water tastes clean and not salty.
Rain water is fresh when collected.

marine_water.definition: Marine water has a high amount of dissolved salt and is found in seas and oceans.
examples: Sea water tastes very salty.
Ocean water cannot be drunk directly.
Salt is made by drying sea water in salterns.

brackish_water.definition: Brackish water has salt content between fresh water and marine water.
examples: Lagoon water is slightly salty.
Batticaloa lagoon has brackish water.
Water where rivers meet the sea is brackish.

water_pollution.definition: Water pollution is the addition of harmful substances that make water unsafe to use.
examples: Throwing plastic bottles into the river makes it dirty.
Factory waste makes the water smell bad.
Washing clothes in the tank pollutes the water.

evaporation.definition: Evaporation is when liquid water changes into water vapor due to heat.
examples: Wet clothes dry in the sun.
Puddles disappear on a hot day.
Water in a pan reduces when boiled.

condensation.definition: Condensation is when water vapor cools and changes back into liquid water.
examples: Water drops form outside a cold glass.
Morning dew appears on leaves.
Bathroom mirrors fog up during a hot shower.

solar_energy.lesson: Energy in Day to Day Life
solar_energy.definition: Solar energy is the energy we get from the sun.
examples: Clothes dry faster in sunlight.
Solar panels on rooftops heat water.
Plants need sunlight to make food.

biomass.lesson: Energy in Day to Day Life
biomass.definition: Biomass is plant or animal material used as fuel to produce energy.
examples: Firewood from trees is used for cooking.
Coconut shells burn to heat water.
Saw dust can be used in a stove.

fossil_fuel.lesson: Energy in Day to Day Life
fossil_fuel.definition: Fossil fuels are fuels formed from ancient plants and animals buried underground.
examples: Petrol in vehicles comes from fossil fuels.
Coal is used in some power plants.
Kerosene oil is a fossil fuel used in lamps.

wind_energy.lesson: Energy in Day to Day Life
wind_energy.definition: Wind energy is power generated by moving air.
examples: Wind makes a kite fly high.
Windmills in Puttalam generate electricity.
Wind dries paddy spread on mats.

hydropower.lesson: Energy in Day to Day Life
hydropower.definition: Hydropower is electricity generated using the energy of flowing water.
examples: Victoria dam produces electricity from water.
Waterfalls can turn turbines to make power.
River water flowing fast has energy.

geothermal_energy.lesson: Energy in Day to Day Life
geothermal_energy.definition: Geothermal energy is heat energy from inside the earth.
examples: Hot springs have naturally warm water.
Geysers shoot hot water from underground.
Some countries use underground heat for electricity.

nuclear_energy.lesson: Energy in Day to Day Life
nuclear_energy.definition: Nuclear energy is energy released from splitting atoms.
examples: Some countries use nuclear power plants for electricity.
The sun produces energy through nuclear reactions.
Nuclear energy produces very high amounts of power.

light.definition: Light is a form of energy that helps us see things.
examples: Sunlight helps you read during the day.
A bulb lights up the room at night.
A torch beam shows the path in darkness.

luminous_objects.definition: Luminous objects are things that produce their own light.
examples: The sun shines brightly in the sky.
A candle flame gives light in the dark.
Fireflies glow at night.

non_luminous_objects.definition: Non-luminous objects do not produce their own light but reflect light from other sources.
examples: The moon shines because of sunlight falling on it.
A book is visible when light falls on it.
Your face reflects light from a bulb.

transparent.definition: Transparent materials allow light to pass through clearly so you can see through them.
examples: You can see through a glass window clearly.
Clear water lets you see fish in the tank.
Clean plastic wrap is transparent.

translucent.definition: Translucent materials allow some light to pass through but you cannot see clearly through them.
examples: Bathroom window glass lets light in but you cannot see outside clearly.
Tissue paper lets light through but is not clear.
Oiled paper glows when light falls on it.

opaque.definition: Opaque materials do not allow light to pass through them.
examples: A cardboard sheet blocks light completely.
A wooden door stops sunlight from entering.
Your hand creates a shadow because it is opaque.

light_ray.definition: A light ray is the narrow path along which light travels in a straight line.
examples: Sunlight comes through a small hole in a straight line.
A laser pointer shows a straight beam of light.
Light through window blinds forms straight lines.

reflection.definition: Reflection is when light bounces back from a surface.
examples: You see your face in a mirror.
Sunlight reflects off a puddle of water.
A shiny spoon reflects light.

sound.definition: Sound is energy produced by vibrations that we can hear.
examples: You hear a bell ring when someone calls you.
A drum makes sound when beaten.
Birds chirp in the morning.

vibration.definition: Vibration is the rapid back and forth movement that produces sound.
examples: A ringing bell shakes quickly.
Your throat vibrates when you speak.
Guitar strings move back and forth when plucked.

music.definition: Music is sound that is pleasant and rhythmic.
examples: A flute plays a sweet tune.
Children sing songs at school assembly.
A violin creates beautiful melodies.

noise.definition: Noise is unpleasant or unwanted sound.
examples: Traffic makes loud noise on the road.
A factory produces disturbing sounds.
Loud horns create uncomfortable noise.

magnetism.definition: Magnetism is the force that attracts certain metals like iron to a magnet.
examples: A magnet picks up iron nails from the floor.
Fridge magnets stick to the steel door.
A compass needle is attracted to Earth's magnetic poles.

magnetic_poles.definition: Magnetic poles are the two ends of a magnet where the magnetic force is strongest.
examples: More iron filings stick at the ends of a bar magnet.
A compass needle points to the North pole.
The two ends of a magnet attract the most clips.

attraction.definition: Attraction is when two opposite magnetic poles pull towards each other.
examples: North pole of one magnet pulls the South pole of another.
A magnet attracts iron nails.
Two different poles of magnets come together.

repulsion.definition: Repulsion is when two similar magnetic poles push away from each other.
examples: North pole pushes away another North pole.
Two South poles of magnets do not come together.
Same poles of magnets move apart.

electricity.definition: Electricity is a form of energy that powers electrical appliances.
examples: A bulb lights up when you switch it on.
Your television runs on electricity.
Fans rotate using electrical energy.

electric_circuit.definition: An electric circuit is a complete path through which electric current flows.
examples: A bulb glows when wires connect it to a battery.
A torch works when the circuit is complete.
Switch closes the circuit to turn on lights.

conductor.definition: A conductor is a material that allows electricity to flow through it easily.
examples: Copper wires carry electricity in your house.
An iron rod conducts electricity well.
Aluminum foil allows current to pass through.

insulator.definition: An insulator is a material that does not allow electricity to flow through it.
examples: Plastic coating protects electric wires.
Rubber slippers keep you safe from electric shocks.
Wood does not conduct electricity.

dry_cell.definition: A dry cell is a portable device that produces electricity using chemicals.
examples: Your remote control uses dry cells.
Wall clocks run on dry cell batteries.
Torches need dry cells to produce light.

solar_cell.definition: A solar cell converts sunlight directly into electricity.
examples: Calculators work using small solar panels.
Rooftop solar panels generate electricity from sunlight.
Garden lights charge during the day using solar cells.

heat.definition: Heat is a form of energy that makes things hot and increases temperature.
examples: Fire from a stove heats the cooking pot.
Sunlight warms your body on a sunny day.
Rubbing your palms together makes them warm.

temperature.definition: Temperature is the measure of how hot or cold something is.
examples: Your body temperature is normally 37 degrees Celsius.
Boiling water has a high temperature.
Ice cream is very cold with low temperature.

expansion.definition: Expansion is when materials become larger when heated.
examples: A balloon becomes bigger when left in the sun.
Railway tracks have gaps to allow expansion in heat.
A metal lid expands when heated with hot water.

contraction.definition: Contraction is when materials become smaller when cooled.
examples: A balloon shrinks when kept in cold water.
Metal becomes slightly smaller when cooled.
Puddles reduce in size on a cold night.

melting.definition: Melting is when a solid changes to liquid due to heat.
examples: Ice cubes melt and become water.
Butter melts in a hot pan.
Chocolate becomes soft and liquid in your hand.

freezing.definition: Freezing is when a liquid changes to solid due to cold.
examples: Water becomes ice in the freezer.
Popsicles freeze and become solid.
Milk becomes ice cream when frozen.

boiling.definition: Boiling is when a liquid changes to gas due to intense heating.
examples: Water in a kettle boils and becomes steam.
Bubbles form when water boils on the stove.
Hot water turns to vapor when boiling.

herbivores.definition: Herbivores are animals that eat only plants.
examples: A cow eats grass from the field.
Rabbits feed on leaves and vegetables.
Elephants eat tree bark and plants.

carnivores.definition: Carnivores are animals that eat only meat.
examples: A lion hunts and eats deer.
Snakes catch and eat rats.
Eagles hunt small animals for food.

omnivores.definition: Omnivores are animals that eat both plants and meat.
examples: Humans eat both rice and chicken.
Crows eat fruits and insects.
Bears eat berries and fish.

food_chain.definition: A food chain shows how energy passes from plants to animals in a sequence.
examples: Grass is eaten by a rabbit, which is eaten by a fox.
Leaves feed caterpillars, which birds eat.
Rice plants feed mice, which snakes catch.

food_web.definition: A food web shows multiple connected food chains in an ecosystem.
examples: Many animals in a forest depend on the same plants.
Different predators hunt the same prey animals.
Plants feed several types of herbivores in a field.

producer.definition: A producer is a green plant that makes its own food using sunlight.
examples: A mango tree produces food in its leaves.
Grass makes its own food using sunlight.
Paddy plants create food through photosynthesis.

consumer.definition: A consumer is an animal that eats plants or other animals for food.
examples: A goat eats grass and is a consumer.
A frog eats insects for energy.
You are a consumer when you eat rice.

weather.definition: Weather is the condition of the atmosphere at a specific place and time.
examples: It is raining heavily today in Colombo.
The morning is sunny but afternoon may be cloudy.
Today is very hot compared to yesterday.

climate.definition: Climate is the average weather pattern of a place over a long period of time.
examples: Nuwara Eliya has a cool climate all year.
Hambantota is usually hot and dry.
The hill country gets more rain than the dry zone.

rainfall.definition: Rainfall is the amount of water that falls from clouds as rain.
examples: Yesterday we had 50 mm of rain.
Heavy rainfall causes puddles on roads.
Monsoon season brings high rainfall.

humidity.definition: Humidity is the amount of water vapor in the air.
examples: Your clothes take longer to dry on humid days.
Coastal areas feel sticky due to high humidity.
Low humidity makes your skin feel dry.

cyclone.definition: A cyclone is a violent storm with very strong winds rotating around a low pressure area.
examples: Cyclones bring heavy rain and strong winds.
Trees fall down during a cyclone.
Fishermen stay ashore when cyclones are predicted.

flood.definition: A flood is when water overflows and covers normally dry land.
examples: Heavy rain causes the river to flood nearby villages.
Roads get covered with water during floods.
Houses near rivers get flooded during monsoons.

drought.definition: A drought is a long period with very little or no rain.
examples: Wells dry up during a drought.
Crops fail when there is a drought.
Tanks become empty in a drought season.

landslide.definition: A landslide is when soil and rocks slide down from higher ground after heavy rain.
examples: Heavy rain causes landslides in hilly areas.
Soil from the mountain slides down and blocks the road.
Houses on slopes are at risk during landslides.
